Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IDBR: Type A. The NANAPHID: A novel aphid-like nanosensor network for real-time measurements of carbohydrates in live plant tissue
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University at Albany (SUNY) and several collaborating organizations, including two other SUNY campuses (SUNY Polytechnic Institute and SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry) and Boston University, to construct and test an aphid-like nanobiosensor whose purpose is to enable real-time monitoring of sugars in living plant tissues. Graduate and undergraduate students will participate in the development of NANAPHID technology. The results obtained in the process of NANAPHID development will be disseminated to the community through lectures, student laboratory exercises and field trips. The project will include a unique Website used to broadcast webinars addressing NANAPHID design, its capabilities, and the latest research results. The NANAPHID will make routine measurements of sugars that will benefit many biological research communities including plant ecologists, investigators at NSF-funded Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) sites, and scientists involved in a broad range of experimental and modelling studies of terrestrial carbon cycling. Applications in crop plant research and management are also promising. For example, the sensor has the potential to replace refractometry as the method of choice for volumetric analysis of sugars.

Non-structural carbohydrates (NSCs) are the currency of energy and growth allocation within plants. These products of photosynthesis are circulated as soluble sugars, whose concentrations are estimated using destructive analytical techniques that have difficulties distinguishing sugars in plant sap from associated cellular materials that get mixed into samples. NANAPHID technology will make real-time in situ measurements of NSC using concentrations in stems, roots, and branches and provide biologists with many new opportunities to monitor critical changes in resource allocation in plants. Tracking these changes in living plants is necessary for directly testing the effect of many environmental changes such as climate, diseases, atmospheric nutrient loads, and acidic deposition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrocatalytic Properties of Nanoporous Platinum Electrodes and Applications in Carbohydrate Biosensors


Glucose sensors have remained an area of focused research activity for several decades since their inception as the first biosensor - or sensors which incorporate biological components. For glucose sensors, that component is an enzyme, glucose oxidase (GOx), which imparts selectivity to the sensor via its recognition capabilities. Efforts have continued seeking to improve these sensors, particularly to enable in vivo, continuous monitoring, otherwise known as continuous glucose monitoring, or CGM. 

The majority of glucose sensor R&D is focused on their common medical application, i.e. the monitoring of blood glucose levels in patients with diabetes. In this work however, a novel application of electrochemical biosensors is explored with ecological and environmental significance, in the monitoring of photosynthate levels in trees. This is significant in part due to the role plants play in the sequestration of atmospheric CO2, which is used as a substrate to produce carbohydrates, and may potentially act as a negative feedback mechanism for rising CO2 levels. The precise levels and composition of the sugars produced via photosynthesis, and subsequently transported, are species-dependent, however it is typically assumed that sucrose will be the predominant form for translocation, due to its non-reducing nature and hence stability. Current methods for obtaining measurements have been found to yield highly variable results, requiring field collection and transport to labs for analysis, including extensive sample preparation. Glucose and sucrose sensors have been produced here in efforts to provide researchers with a simpler technique. The approach in this work has been to first produce glucose sensors, and then use these to form the basis of sucrose sensors through the addition of the enzymes invertase and mutarotase. 

Most of the work discussed in this thesis is focused on the fabrication and functioning of these sensors, including their design and testing. One chapter is devoted exclusively to the properties of high surface area, nanoporous Pt electrodes, deposited electrochemically from solution, which are used as the substrate for sensors. This material is often referred to as Pt black and was investigated for incorporation into sensors to extend the range of operation while maintaining a small sensor size. Experiments were conducted which demonstrated this capability, as well as unexpected advantages, such as an ability to lower the operating potential from the typical value near 600 mV to between 300-400 mV. Investigations were conducted pertaining to this material’s electrocatalytic properties for oxidation of H2O2 to explicate some of the experimental observations. An alternative model is proposed for the determination of kinetic parameters which is motivated by cyclic redox theory, and based on the analogies between adsorption processes, enzyme kinetics, and electrochemical response. This phenomenon has also been referred to as electrosorption, whereby the chemical activity or surface coverage may be altered not just the bulk concentrations (or pressure), but also via potential. 

The remainder of the work details the additional elements of the sensor. Here a 3-layer structure has been used, comprised of, electrodeposited polypyrrole, glutaraldehyde-crosslinked enzyme, and flux-limiting outer membranes. Various aspects of the functionality of these layers, and tests of them are demonstrated. A GUI is also described, which was developed in Python, to facilitate several aspects of sensor production, testing, and implementation. Finally, these various elements are integrated into a system intended to enable measurements of sap samples immediately after collection, as proposed.

As a result of this project, several publications, one Master’s degree and a Ph. D. were awarded.  In addition, several undergraduates/interns were involved in the project resulting in poster presentations and advanced training.
